Posts.Content: Due to start chemo in January but have been told I will start with Taxotere and then have EC. Has anyone else had it this way round?
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Sept78 I have just had a portacath inserted yesterday ready for my chemo starting on 2nd January. I'm quite needle phobic and the oncologist and chemo nurse looked at my veins in my hand and advised that I would be much better off not having chemo through them due to the risks/difficulties of veins not coping. I'm a bit sore from the procedure and was terrified beforehand but actually it was quite straightforward with Christmas music playing in the operating theatre! Might as well ask the question, they can only say no.....
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa I have been given prophylactic antibiotics and anti-fungals at each cycle, beginning on Day 8. I had my cycle 5 yesterday...only one more to go!! For this cycle I have to take them from Day 5 as I really struggled with being so low last cycle and I think the oncologist is concerned that I could be more prone to infection around that time. I also had a change of anti-sickness drugs this cycle as I was so nauseous and vomiting during cycle 4. So instead of taking Emend and ondansetron I was given something called Akynzeo which is a one off tablet taken before chemo.  I've also had my steroids prescribed for longer to help with the nausea. Are you due cycle 5 this week? It does feel nice to know I only have to do this one more time even though I still have to get through the next couple of poopy weeks. Take care xx
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa I have been given prophylactic antibiotics and anti-fungals at each cycle, beginning on Day 8. I had my cycle 5 yesterday...only one more to go!! For this cycle I have to take them from Day 5 as I really struggled with being so low last cycle and I think the oncologist is concerned that I could be more prone to infection around that time. I also had a change of anti-sickness drugs this cycle as I was so nauseous and vomiting during cycle 4. So instead of taking Emend and ondansetron I was given something called Akynzeo which is a one off tablet taken before chemo.  I've also had my steroids prescribed for longer to help with the nausea. Are you due cycle 5 this week? It does feel nice to know I only have to do this one more time even though I still have to get through the next couple of poopy weeks. Take care xx
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: I'm still in. Chemo #4 due on 6th March!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: NiceCuppa yes, I have had emend, ondansetron and domperidone, just starting to ease back on the anti sickness now although still feeling queasy. It seems to be much worse on EC for me than it was on the Docataxel...Two more cycles to go and I cannot wait for it to be over. I have felt so weepy and pathetic, particularly over the last week or so. I just want to feel some level of normality again, this has felt so difficult at times that I'm not sure I can continue feeling this awful.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa Not having swallowing issues, but feeling very nauseous with the EC and vomited on Wednesday after having the first one. I have been given ondansetron as well as domperidone to help but definitely feeling much sicker with this combination of drugs. I am on day 6 and I am also really constipated this time but nervous about using laxatives in case it sets off diarrhoea..... All in all, feeling pretty pathetic and rough, but only 2 more to go. Did you manage to explore having your treatment privately?
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thanks AnnJac I figured it was probably the anti-sickness drugs that is causing the blockage!  Its such a difficult balance between taking enough drugs to not feel and be sick and not stopping things working altogether.....I've emailed the oncologist to ask for some advice.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: NiceCuppa, definitely do not like this new normal! Sending a virtual hug straight back to you. I will have 15 days worth of radiotherapy after chemo then 10 years worth of hormone therapy. I am due to have Zometa infusions every 6 months as well, for 2 years, starting at my next chemo cycle. I can't think of the SEs for the tablets or radiotherapy at the moment, just trying to focus on getting through chemo. Oncologist has said that radiotherapy will be a breeze compared to chemo!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi, I have just been diagnosed last Friday following a routine screening mammogram. Like you I was told at my callback appointment that it was very probably breast cancer. I'm not sure whether I can feel something because I know there is something there now or whether I'm just imagining it. Following my callback appointment I went through a whole range of thoughts and feelings waiting for the results and had even convinced myself that there was definitely nothing there, despite what the radiologist had said.  Please take someone with you for the results. I took my husband who had strict instructions to say nothing and make notes. This has been beneficial to be able to refer back to and to clarify what I was told as such a lot of information to take in. Thinking of you  x
Posts.Title: Just joined the start line!

Posts.Content: I'm currently in cycle 5 and the tiredness has definitely got worse. I would say that actually getting out and going for a gentle walk helps enormously. It is also good for lifting the spirits. xx
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa, I have found EC to be much harder than the docetaxel. I think the effects are just more generalised, not having any energy has been really tough. I've also found it generally harder to bounce back to a level of normality each time, but maybe that's because of the cumulative effect rather than the EC as such. I know what you mean about the bouncing back not really happening until into week 3 and even then not quite right. I've been really struggling with sleeping as well (due to steroids) which means I feel permanently tired. As I had a portacath fitted prior to any chemo and all of my chemo has been given through that I haven't had to contend with knackered veins, but now I need a date to get it removed and I've been told they will wait for a minimum of 3 weeks post chemo in case I end up with an infection before then that they may need to access the line for.... Good luck with your radiotherapy, do you have a start date yet? I am due to have 15 rounds of radiotherapy, I had my radiotherapy planning appointment the day after my last chemo so just waiting for a date to start, but planning for it all to be over by end of May!!! I had planned to go back to work mid-way through radiotherapy, but have decided to wait until its all over and done with so I can have a little more recovery time. I keep getting asked whether I want to go back to work full-time, but I really need to work full-time to pay the bills so not a viable option. Also, my husband had a redundancy threat while I was undergoing treatment so don't feel that I can go back to work anything other than full-time. For anybody starting out on chemo, you can do it. Take one day at a time and be kind to yourself, always xx
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Oh NiceCuppa that's just a whole load of poop you didn't need! You are SO right about going with your instinct, if you don't feel something is right, question, question and question some more!! While I feel I have had excellent care from the chemo unit and nurses I have felt at time that my oncologist could have been a bit better at responding to some of my concerns. I also cold capped and have very very thin hair on top of my head. I've been washing my hair as little as possible to try and preserve what I can, but it is so fine and fragile and still coming out (just not in great big handfuls). I've booked to get it cut really short in a couple of weeks so that the new hair growth can blend in a bit better. I haven't had short hair since I was a kid so will be a huge change for me.  I'm hoping that having some hair will be an advantage when it does start to grow back.  take care xx
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: I'm on my way to the hospital in about half an hour to have (hopefully) chemo #6, my last one! Cycle 5 has been really tough for many reasons but feel like its taken me much longer to bounce back to normal than the other 4 cycles. Some of that is probably the cumulative effect and some probably the addition of Zometa. But I'm so looking forward to finishing chemo and can't quite believe I have managed to get through it. For anybody starting out or in the middle of treatment, just take one day at a time, keep putting one foot in front of the other and do whatever you need to do to get through each day. Pia x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa I now have my radiotherapy treatment schedule and am due to start on the 8th May so I can be all done by the end of May (that's the plan anyway…)  I am planning to go back to work mid-end June but have felt really unsupported by my boss. She hasn't been wanting to involve me in work decisions when I have asked for some involvement, has asked me repeatedly about whether I plan to return full time, despite me saying that was my intention from the start, but has then sent me a text with a job that I might like to apply for!! So I am really not looking forward to going back to work (and I work for the NHS, so you'd think there should be a little more compassion/understanding!!!!). I have been on steroids for 7 days for both cycle 5 & 6 so finally finished them now but I was also prescribed sleeping tablets to take on the same days of steroids which means I get about 3 hours sleep, but like you, I have terrible hot flushes at night which keep me awake. I have been told that they offer acupuncture sessions at the local Maggie's to help with hot flushes so will be checking that out as soon as I feel up to it.  I had a really bad throat/yukky mouth through cycle 5 and was prescribed mouthwash and gelclair which helped to calm things down, might be worth asking? Take care xx
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi Beachwalker19, its good to reach the end isn't it? I'm still suffering with the fog of SEs from my last chemo but so nice to know that its now done and I can focus on the next stage of treatment.  My hands suffered really badly with the docetaxel and I was given an ice pack to use on my hands when they gave me the last dose. I then used that to ease them during the cycle whenever they felt really sore. My hands are now mostly recovered although the skin is very very dry.... xx
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: That made me smile...I will pretend I'm going to a spa No riding for me this morning as horse has gone to her holiday home while I recover from surgery.
Posts.Title: Surgery Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Feeling Terrified...….So, I have my surgery booked for tomorrow morning. I'm having a mastectomy and reconstruction with implant and SNLB at the same time. Any last bits of advice?
Posts.Title: Surgery Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi All, I've had 7/15 sessions and using Aveeno. The radiographer also suggested putting it in the fridge before using it so it could calm things down better. I haven't tried it, but may as treatment progresses. x
Posts.Title: Advice on which moisturiser to use during radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm not completely sure at the moment about where the RT will be focussed. I don't think I properly took in all the information after having the news about the size of the tumour. I'm actually quite comfortable not having an axillary clearance as I'm focussing on the fact that the 3rd lymph node was clear- gotta take the positives wherever they appear! One of my friends from the yard sends me pictures of Annie quite regularly so I can have my horsey fix and tonight she sent me a video of her which cheered me up. I'm hoping to go and see her at the weekend- you're absolutely right- they calm the soul. My riding buddy and I usually talk about riding being good for the soul which I firmly believe to be true. I don't think non-horsey people get what a drug it is. Pic below of my girly, the dark bay in the turquoise rug. Take care Pia x
Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Thank you Karen, I'm feeling very tearful at the moment as such a big shock and it feels like my whole life has just been turned upside down :(
Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, no, not planning to do a clearance as the third node was clear so they said it wasn't necessary just throw in the radiotherapy instead! The only 'risk factor' I fit is having close family members having had ovarian/breast cancer (mum and aunt) so I guess its just unlucky to get it...despite being fit and active.  Are you managing to get out on your horse? Mine has been turned away for a holiday but hoping/planning to bring her back into work when I'm recovered from surgery and allowed to ride again.  My head is all over the place, sometimes feeling positive and sometimes wanting to collapse in a heap of tears and bury my head in the sand pretending it isn't happening. x
Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: So after having a mastectomy earlier this month I have just received my results this afternoon and am feeling shell shocked. I had been told that I would likely need chemotherapy after surgery as my tumour was a grade 3 so not totally surprised about the need for chemo.. It turns out that what they had seen on scans and diagnosed as a 12mm invasive tumour along with widespread high grade DCIS was actually 60mm of invasive tumour. My lymph nodes had looked clear on scans but 2 out of the 3 removed had micro involvement....my head is spinning with the news. Still waiting to hear whether I am HER2 positive or not as my initial biopsy was borderline negative so is being repeated. So chemo it is for me, followed by radiotherapy. I can't quite believe this is happening, I was fit and well and very active a couple of months ago....
Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks, that made me smile I'm usually a pretty positive person so I'm sure once I have manged to metabolize this new reality I will come out fighting. I hope so anyway.....It does make you take stock of who and what is important in your life. No time or energy for negative people from now on I'm my number one priority. This may be easier said than done....
Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa_F so sorry you find yourself here but it is a useful place to have questions answered. I finished chemo in April and was also lucky enough to have my treatment covered by my husband's private medical insurance. I wasn't given the choice of treatment at home, so can't help you with that as I had all of my chemo at the local private hospital. I cannot fault the team delivering care, they were kind, responsive to my needs and very caring. There was also a Maggie's representative on site who I spoke to a number of times during treatment. There were some disadvantages though such as not having access to the breast care nurses as they didn't have any information on my treatment they were unable to answer any questions. I also didn't meet anybody else going through treatment at the same time which may have been beneficial to provide support. In some respects I felt quite isolated having my treatment where I did so I can totally understand your concerns.  However, if faced with the decision of whether to go privately or through the NHS again, I would definitely go private. Good luck with whatever you decide. xx
Posts.Title: **MAY 2019 BREAST CANCER CHEMOTHERAPY CHAT**
